title: Girls given free chance to try out hockey
text:
Girls given free chance to try out hockey By: Perry Bergson Report Error 
Hockey Brandon hopes to build on unprecedented local growth in the youngest levels of girls’ hockey as it hosts Esso Fun Day on Saturday. 
The free ice time, which begins at noon at the Sportsplex, allows newcomers to experience the sport under the watchful eye of on-ice adult instructors and female midget and Brandon Midget AAA Wheat Kings players. 
Bringing equipment is preferred, although girls with helmets and skates will be allowed on the ice. 
Myles Hubbard, Hockey Brandon’s director of female hockey, said it’s the second time the program has been offered. 
“It’s just an introduction and playing a few games,” Hubbard said. “Hopefully they’ll continue on with our rec program that starts shortly after that.” 
The rec program, which is in its second year, runs every Thursday at 6:30 p.m., and will include 15 ice times starting Oct. 15. It’s $200 for newcomers. 
Hubbard said the recreation program is a good fit for girls who are new to the sport. 
The fun day builds on recent success that Hockey Brandon has had in growing the sport in the city. 
The city will ice three atom teams for the first time this winter and has 30 girls in novice and 26 signed up for rec hockey, which is open to girls born from 2006 to 2010. 
“It’s really at the bottom end that it’s exploding,” Hubbard said. “That’s what we wanted. A couple of years ago we sat down and said what do we have to do and decided that we needed to get huge numbers in our younger age groups, which gives us something that we can build the program with.” 
Brandon currently fields one team in each of the peewee, bantam and midget age groups, numbers that could grow in the future. 
“We realized that we need to get girls playing with girls right off the bat at a young age,” Hubbard said. “They don’t have to go and play with the boys. They can wait until our girls’ program starts in atom and then they go right into our girls’ program. It gets them into an environment where they feel comfortable with other girls.” 
The fun day falls during the fifth annual World Girls’ Hockey Weekend, a global initiative by the International Ice Hockey Federation to introduce girls to the game and to celebrate the rapidly growing sport. 
While there are an increasing number of scholarship opportunities in Canada and the United States, Hubbard said that’s not the focus for Hockey Brandon. 
“That’s a small part of the whole thing,” Hubbard said. “It’s getting the girls out and having fun and competing and then hopefully making it a lifelong sport. Like everybody else, we all end up in rec hockey as we get older and we just want the girls as they become women to still play the sport.” 
To register, call Hockey Brandon’s office at 204-726-3550.
